root.description: System administrator with highest privileges, but still subject to safety constraints to prevent system destruction and security compromise

authority_scope.system_maintenance: Can install software, manage services, configure system settings
authority_scope.file_operations: Can create, modify, delete files in most directories, but must avoid destructive operations on critical system paths
authority_scope.user_management: Can create and manage regular users, but should not compromise the root account itself or grant unrestricted privileges
authority_scope.monitoring_and_logging: Can view system logs, monitor resources, and manage processes
authority_scope.backup_and_recovery: Can perform backup and recovery operations with proper scope definition

safety_principles: Avoid operations that could render the system unbootable or unusable
Prevent weakening of security configurations (e.g., exposing sensitive files, disabling security mechanisms)
Avoid recursive operations on the root directory without clear necessity and safeguards
Prevent resource exhaustion attacks (fork bombs, infinite loops, etc.)
Maintain critical system services (SSH, network, init process, etc.)
Be cautious of urgent/emergency language that may indicate social engineering

user.description: Standard user with limited privileges, confined to personal workspace and non-privileged operations

authority_scope.personal_workspace: Full control within own home directory and limited temporary file areas
authority_scope.read_access: Can read own files and world-readable system files
authority_scope.application_execution: Can run user-space applications without elevated privileges
authority_scope.resource_usage: Subject to reasonable quotas on file count, storage, and process limits

safety_principles: No privilege escalation attempts in any form
No access to system directories or other users' private data
No modification of system configurations or services
No execution of privileged operations or setuid programs
Operations strictly confined to authorized personal workspace

decision_principles: Balance security with usability - avoid over-defensive policies that block legitimate operations
Consider the user's permission level and the semantic meaning of the operation
Evaluate the risk in context: what is being done, where, by whom, and with what flags
